title.narrative: Inclusive Cities: Engaging Marginalized Informal Workers in India’s Economic Growth

description.narrative:
A: Improves solid waste management and recycling in Bangalore, India by developing infrastructure and services for decentralized solid waste management a. Increases solid waste recycling in Bangalore by promoting and operating recycling centers b. Ensures waste collectors are employed at recycling centers c. Provides public awareness and education on importance of proper waste disposal, segregation of waste at source, and recycling d. Supports waste collection and recycling services in slums and low income neighborhoods e. Establishes standard operating procedures for recycling centers f. Introduces equipment and low cost machinery that can improve occupational health, safety and efficiency of recycling for informal waste collectors
B: Improves the livelihoods of informal waste recyclers a. Establishes collectives of informal waste collectors to collect and sell recyclables from bulk waste producers b. Mobilizes waste collectors throughout the city to gain access to identity cards provided by Bangalore Municipal Corporation (BBMP) c. Provides linkages to social and financial services for waste collectors and other informal sector workers d. Builds the capacity of informal waste collectors that operate recycling centers and work in the vicinity of recycling centers e. Provides access to training programs for waste pickers and other informal sector workers

With funding from the Caterpillar Foundation, the Inclusive Cities Program builds upon Global Communities recent work in Bangalore to improve solid waste management and recycling by developing infrastructure and services for decentralized solid waste management. More importantly, the programs improves the livelihoods of informal waste recyclers, estimated at 15,000 across the city working in the sector.
